unnormalised: New data from the 2021 census of India reveals interesting trends. While the full report is still awaited, preliminary figures indicate a total population of 1.39 billion. This represents a growth rate of approximately 1.2% per annum since the last census in 2011. Significant variations exist between states, with some southern states showing slower growth compared to northern and eastern regions.
normalised: New data from the two thousand twenty one census of India reveals interesting trends. While the full report is still awaited, preliminary figures indicate a total population of one point three nine billion. This represents a growth rate of approximately one point two percent per annum since the last census in two thousand eleven. Significant variations exist between states, with some southern states showing slower growth compared to northern and eastern regions.

unnormalised: Interestingly, the child sex ratio (0-6 years) has shown a marginal improvement compared to 2011 but remains a concern at 918 females per 1000 males. The literacy rate has also increased to 77.7%, up from 74.04% a decade ago. Urbanization continues to be a prominent trend, with nearly 35% of the population now residing in urban areas.
normalised: Interestingly, the child sex ratio (zero to six years) has shown a marginal improvement compared to two thousand eleven but remains a concern at nine hundred and eighteen females per one thousand males. The literacy rate has also increased to seventy seven point seven percent, up from seventy four point zero four percent a decade ago. Urbanization continues to be a prominent trend, with nearly thirty five percent of the population now residing in urban areas.

unnormalised: Experts predict that India's population may surpass China’s by 2027, becoming the world’s most populous nation. Detailed data on demographics, socio-economic indicators, and housing conditions are expected to be released in subsequent reports. The census data is crucial for informed policymaking and resource allocation at both central and state government levels.
normalised: Experts predict that India's population may surpass China's by two thousand twenty seven, becoming the world's most populous nation. Detailed data on demographics, socio-economic indicators, and housing conditions are expected to be released in subsequent reports. The census data is crucial for informed policymaking and resource allocation at both central and state government levels.
